Let us be thankful that things wear so fair an aspect and have hitherto turned out so well. I doubt not but we shall all by and by be wonderfully comfortable.

I gratified all hands here, as I myself had been, by informing them of your first step towards graduation. “Not of works, lest we should boast!” the Apostle says;Eph. 2:9. but really it is fair enough to go thro’ so handsomely, without aid from any grinder or honerSomeone to sharpen his wits: a tutor. whatever, but purely by one’s own resources. For the rest, doubt not that your moodiness was temporary; the slackening of the long-stretched cord, when the arrow was shot away: in a day the yew will tighten it again. The world is but beginning for you yet; and it is wide and broad, far beyond what you conjecture. It really is, Jack; tho’ in hypochondriacal moments, you will not believe a word of it. Come to me wherever I be, when you have finished; and take plenty of time to consider what your next step must be. While either of us has a home, the other cannot want one.

We are all got over with whole bones to this new country;From Mainhill and Hoddam Hill to Scotsbrig. and every soul of us, our mother to begin with, much in love with it. The house is in bad order; but we hope to have it soon repaired; and for farming purposes, it is an excellent “shell of a house.” Then we have a linn [waterfall] with crags and bushes, and a “fairy knowe [knoll]” tho’ no fairies that I have seen yet; and, cries our Mother, abundance of grand thready peats, and water from the brook, and no reek and no HonourGen. Matthew Sharpe, the landlord at Mainhill. to pester us! To say nothing, cries our father, of the eighten yeacre [acre] of the best barley in the country; and bog-hay, adds Alick, to fatten scores of young beasts!

In fact making all allowance for newfangledness, it is a much better place, so far as I can judge, than any our people have yet been in; and among far better and kindlier sort of people. I believe of a truth they will find themselves much obliged to his Honour for persecuting them away. Long life to his Honour! I myself like the place considerably better, tho’ I have slept but ill yet, and am billus enough. But I have mounted your old straw-hat again; and fairly betaken me to work; and should, as we say Aberdeen-awa, “be bauld to compleen.”

The other day, just on Monday indeed w[ith my] letter in my hand, I met “Wull Eggar” or “Don [Quixote”?]Unidentified. of Deerhopes, mounted on a clipt and garnished quadruped, riding with an air of daring enterprise towards Ecclefechan. Laughter had fled from his diaphragm, and he told me at last that he was on his way to Annan, there to set up, in place of Waugh,John Smith Waugh. or rather in absence of him. Thus round and round about go we! Poor Waugh is still in the Kings Arms inn; madly in love, they say, and persuaded that the Chambermaid has a mind to do him bodily harm, for reasons to herself best known. Seriously, I wish I could see Waugh: he has no friend on Earth, scarcely any relative; and Heaven knows, I would gladly enough see him act more wisely.

I have had a vile bout with this life of Hoffmann: it is far the worst, and has been far the most troublesome of them all. Henceforth [I hope] to supply M’Cork regularly. Write more at large if you can next time. Alick goes to Whitsuntide fair at Dumfries tomorrow, and this should go with him; and all hands are already sound asleep. I have still another notule to write, which you will not fail to deliver. Good night! I am ever your affe Brother,
docBody.name: Thomas Carlyle.

ps.p: Is JohnstonJames Johnston. gone? My best wishes to him, if not.

div3.sourceNote: TC-DI, 17 April 1828. Addr: Advocates’ Library. MS: Mitchell Library, Glasgow. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 9:387–88, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO DAVID IRVING

docBody.p: I shall now make to you in writing the proposal I lately made in words, on the part of Herr von Lichtenthaler, Keeper of the Royal Library at Munich.See 4:361TC to JAC, 16 April, where Carlyle describes his earlier conversation with Irving.

It appears that in the Munich Library there are about 150,000 Duplicate volumes, “some of them very valuable”: these the Directors are desirous of exchanging with similarly superfluous Duplicates in other Libraries.This information had come through John at this time staying in Munich (see 4:357TC to JAC, 16 April). Should there be any considerable stock of such in your Collection, perhaps you might not feel disinclined to this negotiation; in which case, a Catalogue of the Munich Duplicates, with the price and external character of each work, would be transmitted to you; and a corresponding Catalogue on your part being sent thither, the business could be transacted without difficulty, and, as might be hoped, to mutual advantage.

If you judge it suitable to entertain this proposal, I shall beg of you to let me know: mentioning in general the number of volumes you may have it in your power so to offer in exchange.Irving thought the Advocates’ Library only had “a few hundreds” (see 4:361TC to JAC, 16 April). The affair, once entered upon, may be prosecuted and concluded in concert with the Baron von Zetto, Bavarian Ambassador in London.Auguste von Cetto (1794–1847), Bavarian ambassador to London, later to Vienna, son of Anton von Cetto (1756–1830), diplomat.

I make a similar application to Mr Ellis of the British Museum,Sir Henry Ellis (1777–1869), principal librarian of the British Museum, 1827–56; knighted, 1833. to Dr Bandinel of the Bodleian Library;Bulkeley Bandinel (1781–1861), principal librarian of the Bodleian, 1813–60. and to no other. If the Munich Duplicates cannot be disposed of in this way, they are to be sold.

closer.salute: Believe me always, / My Dear Sir, / Most sincerely Your’s, /

docBody.name: Thomas Carlyle—

div3.sourceNote: TC-WT, [22? Aug. 1826]. MS: EUL. William Tait was publishing TC’s German Romance, printed by James Ballantyne and his foreman Daniel M’Corkindale. Dated by TC’s expectation that the last proofs would be sent just before this. For discussion of the title, see TC to WT, 31 July 1826, TC to WT, 10 Aug. 1826. [This letter, transcribed from the MS and pbd. at CL 12:381–83, is now placed at its proper chronological location. A facsimile of the abstracted version it supersedes, pbd. at CL 4:127–28, can be viewed in the Revision History.]
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM TAIT

docBody.p: I have sent up my last packet of sheets to honest Mr M’Corkindale, the most faithful and best of Printers; with directions to give you the Revise of the Preface and Title-page; which so soon as you have satisfied yourself about it, they can fold up (uncut) in the shape of a letter, and send me by post, to look at once more before it go to press.

I bow without repining to your condemnation (if irrevocable) of this unhappy Title; judging you to understand far more about it than I. Nevertheless, if we except “German Novelists with” &c, which was the Title I had all along in my head, I cannot think of any better, or even of any other that shall express the gist and purpose of the Book. The present one undoubtedly is hard and heavy; but it has this first and most indispensable quality; and to my own mind, it does not appear altogether uninviting of investigation, or unlikely to attract the better class of readers. Its hardness of intelligibility, provided it be really at last intelligible, may perhaps rather provoke curiosity than satisfy it. A reader often wondering what the deuce it means, will look into the Preface for information; and be tempted, who knows, (consummation devoutly to be wished!)Hamlet 3.1. to table his cash, and take the Book home in his pocket! Such was my view of it: but as I said, it is the view of one who can pretend to none but theoretical knowledge on the matter. For the rest, do not think that I like this Title; on the contrary I rather dislike it, and have chosen it only as the bad best; as expressing (the former one being forestalled) the object of the Book in plain rugged and firm language, and distinguishing our Novelists at a glance, from all the Roscoe, Gillies & Company fraternity,Thomas Roscoe, The German Novelists, 4 vols. (London, 1826); see 4:120TC to WT, 31 July 1826, 161TC to NHJ, 4 Dec. 1826. R. P. Gillies, German Stories, 3 vols. (Edinburgh, 1826); see 4:162TC to NHJ, 4 Dec. 1826. beyond the possibility of confusion. I confess however that I rather have a pique at dandyism both in men and books; and so perhaps rather an undue tolerance for the opposite excess. “Highways and Byeways,” for instance, is a book which I should never buy, or care for looking into; and I am too apt to forget that many others might.

One other thing I may add: “Romances,” “Tales,” “Novels” &c should not (unless in the very last extremity) be the Title of your work. First, because it is a Title which promises nothing, and has been used already by many men and women, Holcraft (Gillies), Cruikshank (?) &c &c.Richard Holcraft, Tales from the German (London, 1826) and Tales of Humour and Romance Selected from Popular German Writers (London, 1829); German Popular Stories, illus. by George Cruikshank (London, 1823); see 4:162TC to NHJ, 4 Dec. 1826. Secondly because the Book is not of Novels but of Novelwriters, or at the utmost of Novel-writing. I think you should keep this steadily in view.

After all, I believe, the Title is of very little real moment in the long run; for if the Book is a ragwort no name of rose or lavender will keep it from offending the nostril; and vice versa also. Therefore do you and Mr Ballantyne take solemn counsel together; read over the Preface, and settle the whole according to your best judgement: I shall scarcely object, I think, be the result what it may. All I want is that it were settled: yet let not this hurry you too much, for I can wait.

I have sent Mr Buchanan’s books, which have long been lying on my conscience: be so good as return him my best thanks along with them, and real regret that I should have so overstretched his goodness. Desire him also from me to direct you how to pay Perthes & Besser if he can; I am very anxious that the debt were cancelled.Mr. Buchanan of Leith, a friend of William Tait, mentioned as a source for borrowing German books (3:325TC to CTA, 13 May 1825) and as one who dealt with Hamburg booksellers (4:57TC to NHJ, 14 March 1826); probably Thomas B., merchant, of 6 Leopold Pl., Leith; not David B. as noted in 4:128TC to WT, 22 Aug. 1826. Perthes & Besser were Hamburg booksellers (4:120TC to WT, 31 July 1826).

My engagements at present are not at all of a literary sort: and I promise or threaten you that you are likely to have the refusal of my next literary enterprise, be what it may. The “Literary Gazette”Tait was presumably still planning to publish a literary magazine. TC had first mentioned Tait’s plan in Dec. 1820 (1:299TC to AC, 23 Dec. 1820); in fact, Tait’s Edinburgh Magazine, apparently an extension of these plans, did not start until 1832 (6:115TC to WT, 5 Feb. 1832). is a thing I am still by no means disinclined to, provided I could in any way see how it was to be managed and gone thro’ with; more especially, as I intend taking up my abode in Edinr next winter at a hearth of my own. I wish you would study the project maturely, and have some decisive news of it to tell me when I see you.

I declare I am absolutely wae to take leave of the good M’Corkindale[;] thank him from me for all his punctuality and clearness of judgement, unexampled in my previous experience of printers, and tell him that I hope soon and often to meet him again.
docBody.name: Thomas Carlyle—

ps.p: Your [boo]ks (German ones) I design sending by the first opportunity of a carrier. I expect you will sell them without difficulty, at least when our as yet nameless work is out.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[TCh] [TCH], [21 or 28 May 1827?]. MS: New College Library, Edinburgh. Hitherto unpbd. JWC had known Thomas Chalmers previously; see Reminiscences 215, and JBW to TC, 25 May 1822. Probably dated during the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland, 1827, when Chalmers is known to have been in Edinburgh, arriving from London, Tues., 22 May, presumably for a week; date of departure unknown. He was currently prof. of moral philosophy at St. Andrews. No other visit to Edinburgh is recorded in the period when JWC lived at Comely Bank in William Hanna, Memoirs of … Thomas Chalmers, 4 vols. (Edinburgh, 1849–52). John G. Lorimer (1804–68), a son of JWC’s minister at Haddington (see JBW to EA, 6 Oct. 1819), had written to Chalmers about JWC’s marriage, 30 Jan.: “Your friend Miss Welsh was a few months ago married to a Mr. Carlile a great friend & fellow countryman of Mr. Irving’s. He once studied for the Church but I believe his sentiments undergoing a change for the worse he abandoned it and has devoted his time since chiefly to German Literature—subsisting himself by translating Dramatic Works & Romances— He has advertised 4 vols of the latter at present—designating himself the author of Schiller’s life—a work which certainly discovers a mind of very high talent but which I should have rejoiced to have seen imbued with Christian principles” (MS: New College Library). [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 12:383–84, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: JWC TO THOMAS CHALMERS

docBody.p: Could you possibly come and see me during your stay in Edinr? I have changed my name and residence since we saw each other; but my heart is still the same, and I have still grateful recollections of your goodness. It would give me a true pleasure to welcome you to my own house, and my husband, too, would be quite glad to renew his acquaintance with you. Perhaps you will take breakfast with us some morning? I should be so sorry were you to take the trouble of coming, and find us out; as might readily enough happen in a forenoon. Do comply with my request if you can. I am always / respectfully and affectionately / yours / Jane Welsh Carlyle / Monday morning / 21 Comely Bank

ps.p: Our breakfast hour is half past nine; and the walk hither from the town delightful.

div3.sourceNote: EI-TCh [TCH], [mid-Sept. 1827]. MS: New College Library, Edinburgh. TC considered applying for the chair of moral philosophy at the new London University, autumn, 1827. Irving had incorrectly told TC sometime before 13 Sept. that Thomas Chalmers was to be the new prof. of moral philosophy; see JWC to JAC, 13 Sept. This unpbd. extract from Irving’s letter to Chalmers on this subject provides a further example of the keenness with which TC pursued the possible chair and should be read in conjunction with TC and JWC’s letters of Sept.–Oct. (particularly JWC to ADBM, 2 Sept., TC to JAC, 5 Sept., TC to AC, 11 Sept., and TC to AC, 23 Oct.). [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 12:384–85, has been assigned a document date of 15 Sept. and is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: EDWARD IRVING TO THOMAS CHALMERS

docBody.p: The thing which occasions my writing at present is as follows: My friend Thomas Carlyle whom the world now knows as the author of several works connected with Literature wrote me concerning a purpose which he had of applying either for the Moral Philosophy or Rhetoric Chair in the London University. In reply to which I wrote to him mentioning in confidence how you had been entreated to accept the former, and explaining to him how vain it was for any other man living to enter into any competition with you, set as the Directors were upon you, and all-interested in your acceptance of it. But nothing of this kind was necessary to determine him: for the moment he heard of your name being before the Directors, he resigned all thought of presenting him: and began to prosecute enquiries by the help of his friend Mr Jeffrey concerning the Chair of Rhetoric: in the pursuit of which certain things came to his knowledge which led him to believe that you had given a formal refusal to their application, and at the same time he found the sphere of the Rhetoric Chair so narrowed & circumscribed in the idea of the directors, as to lead him greatly to prefer the other, if it was open to his pursuit. But being unwilling to take any measures whatever until he shall have ascertained exactly the ground which you occupy at present, he has requested me to write to you which I also was willing and indeed offered to do, in order to have from yourself the information direct. Would you be kind enough to let me know by return of Post: for it would seem in the Month of November the Professorships are all to be appointed to. Be assured that I will make no improper use of the information which you are pleased to communicate to me.

My feelings towards Thomas Carlyle are exactly such as your feelings are towards Mr Jeffrey with whom he takes counsel in this matter. I trust and pray that the Lord would open his eyes to the beauty and all-suffering which is on the face of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ. And I hope the Lord is leading him in that way. He has a very deep feeling of “what is true and honest and pure and lovely and of good report”;Cf. Phil. 4:8. and I think he has a right idea of “Wisdom”: but it has not yet pleased the Lord to bring him to that condition of ‘the babe’ to whom it [is] his will that the things of Christ should be revealed.Cf. Matt. 11:25. What a mystery, Dear Doctor, that is of the great Counsel of Eternity, to bereave the glory of the human understanding by the foolishness of preaching, that no flesh should glory in his presence.1 Cor. 1:29. And how needful for an intellect like yours to bear it in even mind. For myself I ever pray to be enabled “so to receive that I may be worthy to understand; so to believe that understanding may come as the reward of my faith.” My Dear friend Carlyle is making approaches to this ground but hath not yet been permitted to stand firmly upon it. And being conscious with myself that he is an enemy of all unrighteousness, and of all those who profane the holy name of our Lord Jesus Christ, and set at naught his Holy Gospel, I feel that he is of that class “who are not against us and therefore for us.”Cf. Matt. 12:30. For if I thought that he was to oppose in any thing the name of Christ I durst not upon my fealty to my Sovereign Lord give him any encouragement, in any way, remembering the word of the blessed Apostle “that we should not bid such God-speed”2 John 10. But feeling on the other hand convinced that he is a proper person to reclaim the rage of those disputers of this world who would cast off the bonds of our God and his Church, and so lead man into other views of truth. I feel very desirous that he might succeed in this object, and should augur[?] better for[?] his success than of any other Moralist of the School of Stewart and Reid or even Locke,Dugald Stewart (1753–1828) and Thomas Reid (1710–96), both Scottish profs. of moral philosophy; John Locke (1632–1704). and I can find no one except “our old Coleridge” who goes higher. …

div3.sourceNote: TC-FWB, [2 Dec. 1827]. Addr: at Dr Thomson’s, / George-street—. MS: Stadtarchiv, Offenbach am Main, West Germany. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by TC’s “virulent sore throat” which he had for “about a week” before his mother’s and sister Jean’s arrival for a visit on Wed., 5 Dec. (see TC to JCE, 22 Dec.). Ferdinand Wilhelm Becker (1805–34), son of Karl Ferdinand Becker (1775–1849), philologist and physician in Offenbach; educ. Offenbach; asst. librarian at the Advocates’ Library, Edinburgh, 1820 to ca. 1823; returning to Germany he became M.D., Berlin, 1826; after living in Scotland again until late 1829, he practiced in Berlin until his death. See also TC to JAC, 10 Jan. 1832. A note enclosed with this letter in TC’s hand (presumably to Becker but of a different date) reads: “I have got a loan of this Heftlein [Booklet], which in my turn I very gladly lend you. Why do you not come down to see us? / T. Carlyle.” [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 12:386, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO FERDINAND WILHELM BECKER

p.foreign: Für meine Sünde, da hab’ ich eine tüchtige Sore-throat bekommen, und, unter andern, die ganze liebe Nacht durchwacht. Kommen Sie hie[r]her, mein theurer Arzt, um mich armen zu kuriren, der wenigstens nach Mass und Regel zu verderben! Eiligst und schlennigst; denn:

l.note: A parody of Mignon’s song, Wilhelm Meisters Lehrjahre (Works 23:277).

p.name: T. Carlyle—
p.note:
“Sunday Morning, Comely Bank. / My dear Herr Doctor, / For my sins I have caught a bad sore throat, and, among other things, lain awake the whole blessed night. Come you here, my dear Doctor, and cure poor unfortunate me, or at least kill me by rule and proper prescription! Harrassed and in great haste, for
I’m dizzy, I’m burning
I’m completely on fire
Only the man who knows the sore throat
Knows what I’m going through!
Your unfortunate / T. Carlyle.”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-FWB, [3? Dec. 1827]. MS: Stadtarchiv, Offenbach am Main, West Germany. Hitherto unpbd. Probably written the morning of JWC to FWB, [3 Dec.], written “Monday evening,” indicating that the blistering of TC’s throat was the treatment Becker tried in response to JWC’s plea in this letter. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 12:387, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: JWC TO FERDINAND WILHELM BECKER

docBody.p: I am sorry to disturb you so early; but I no longer know what else to do.

We have had a dreadful night again— Tho’ he took the powder, he has not been able to sleep above five minutes together for the stuff in his throat— and that is now worse than ever, so that tho’ he would most gladly take the jelly or the other powderTC had been gargling with “a solution of cream-of-tartar and black-currant jelly” on 29 Nov. (4:287TC to JAC, 29 Nov.). as you prescribed he cannot get over one drop. I have tried a new poultice and steaming and every thing I could think of to no purpose—so for heaven’s sake come

ps.p: I will have breakfast ready for you here

div3.sourceNote: JWC-FWB, [3 Dec. 1827]. Addr: George Street. MS: Stadtarchiv, Offenbach am Main, West Germany. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 12:387, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: JWC TO FERDINAND WILHELM BECKER

docBody.p: We have applied the blister as you directed, and it seems to be rising well; but still the swelling and inflamation are nowise abated.The swelling burst on Wed., 5 Dec. (4:297TC to JCE, 22 Dec.). Mr Carlyle has not be[en] able to swallow anything whatever, since you saw him, his throat being quite closed up, so that to get the powder over, and in that way have a chance of sleep, is out of the question. What makes the matter worse he has an excessive desire to drink. Can you suggest anything else instead of the powder? For the prospect of another such night as the last, or perhaps even a worse is quite frightful. Would leeches be of any use—do you think
Pray write your instructions for my Servant is entirely stupid

ps.p: Monday evening

div3.sourceNote: TC-FWB, 6 Feb. 1828. MS: Stadtarchiv, Offenbach am Main, West Germany. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 12:388, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO FERDINAND WILHELM BECKER

docBody.p: Will you please to accept of this small Lancet-case; and sometimes when you shed human blood in this way, will you think of the unhappy man whose throat you cruelly scarified, and whom by cinnamon-drops of that oleum diaboli, and a thousand cunning practices you nevertheless delivered from that “element of slime,”See 4:317TC to JAC, 1 Feb.. in which he threatened to make shipwreck?
We want much to see you the first hour you have leisure. Mrs C. is playing Kennst du das Land [Knowst thou the land]; but astonishes me much by her criticisms of it.

closer.salute: Believe me always, / Your’s most truly, /

div3.sourceNote: TC-[HI], [mid-May 1828]. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. For Henry Inglis (1806–86), Edinburgh lawyer, see TC to JAC, 29 Nov. 1827. Dated by the Carlyles’ departure from Edinburgh, apparently on 25 May (in fact a Sat.), for Craigenputtoch; it is probably one of the communications with Inglis about “Books and other trifles” that TC apologizes for in TC to HI, [22 May], and should be read as written a few days before that letter (see TC to HI, 22 May 1828). For J. K. A. Musaeus (1735–87), see TC to JBW, 11 May 1823; TC had trans. some of his tales for the first vol. of German Romance (1827); he had presumably lent Inglis his own copy of Volksmärchen der Deutschen as he was encouraging Inglis to read German. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 12:388, has been assigned a document date of 15 May 1828 and is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO HENRY INGLIS

docBody.p: You will surely come down and see me before I go? I am never occupied; or rather always—with trifles, and des choses facheuses [vexatious things]
My address is: / Craigenputtoch, / Dumfries—
I know not but I shall even now apply to you for some Book: if I do, and fail to see you, it will be by Letter. We leave this house on Wednesday night or Thursday, the Town next morning.
Will you lay out Müsaus, if you have done with it, and I will make the servant call. But come and see us!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
